website_summaries.verdict: Designed to work in NAS systems, this hard drive provides huge storage capacity options up to 10 TB.
pros: High-capacity HDD that's especially made for network attached storage (NAS) systems, although it will work in individual computers, too
Can handle the constant workloads that NAS systems encounter
Available in storage capacities between 1 TB and 10 TB
Includes a huge cache area for better speed
cons: Doesn't include any cables, user manual, or mounting screws

customer_reviews.title: DO NOT BUY!! $83 and it last 85 days.  is that a good deal?
customer_reviews.text: Purchased March 20, 2018. HDD Crapped out Jun 15, 2018. Almost hit 90 days. needless to say, it's crappy. Update: Sent WD email since they have warranty. Been 5 days of Radio silence. Update. WD finally responded. Boilerplate “haha. Now we can give you refurbished one back and too bad about your data. Serves you right for buying from us. Did we mention haha?” Anyway. My mistake hopefully prevents you from making the same.
customer_reviews.author: TS

customer_reviews.title: Slow performance
customer_reviews.text: Uses slower SMR tech to save money. Look it up. WD is not telling you that they are cheaping out on their drives and is falsely advertising their drive capabilities and performance.
customer_reviews.author: azezal

customer_reviews.title: zero Star
customer_reviews.text: Dec 2016 - The partition has crashed after just under 1 years use, seeking replacement... Paid postage to Vietnam ($60) and after well over a month received a replacement in early 2017... -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Oct 2017 - The replacement drive has crashed in the last day after less than 10 mths operation. (From 5 bad sectors in quick sucession) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The reliability of these hard drives (fitted in a Synology DS214 NAS) is APPALLING. I* would NOT recommend the brand or product PERIOD. * Context: I am an Electronic Engineer with extensive experience in the IT environment.
customer_reviews.author: Atomo

customer_reviews.title: Great drive. Beware of deceiving sellers
customer_reviews.text: I have 6 of these WD 6TB in a Synology NAS. These are great, silent, reliable. Never had a problem with them (just know that everything has a lifetime...) However, beware of the sellers on Amazon: I didn't check on my last purchase (of 2 WD 6TB - NEW) and received 2 drives weirdly packaged. I installed them and both show "Power On time" of more than 35000 hours. More than 4 years of usage and sold as NEW. Advice: Check recent feedbacks on the sellers before ordering. Check Manufactured date before installing, check "Power on Time" on the drive after install, before using.
customer_reviews.author: Fred

customer_reviews.title: Much to my dismay they use SMR
customer_reviews.text: I have gone through a few of these drives, but it's what I have in my NAS, so I replace like with like. This may be my last WD Red Drive. When I look for a NAS drive I look for reliability above all else. Sure, it's a home NAS, but I don't want to have to think about it. I just want it to work. After my most recent order I saw that Western Digital was using SMR technology (Shingled Magnetic Recording) for these drives. This is great as it provides more GB per platter. Bad if you are looking for long term reliability. Hopefully I have a while before my next drive failure. My fingers are certainly crossed.
customer_reviews.author: John T.

customer_reviews.title: I have had 2 drives fail in my NAS.
customer_reviews.text: I have a Synology DS1817+ NAS, I originally only had 1 WD Red 4TB drive that i would use to store my data on and after 6 months the drive has FAILED, no raid array and no other backups, so i sent the drive off to a data recovery service and they were unsuccessful at retrieving any data off of it. I have now scene switched to Seagate Iron Wolf Pro Drives witch are a little bit more pricer but have a 5 year warranty, with a 2 year warranty on data recovery, unlike WD witch has only a 3 year warranty with no data recovery service.
customer_reviews.author: kr

customer_reviews.title: the drive was placed at the bottom of the package and the bubble wrap is placed on the top
customer_reviews.text: The drive has no wrapping whatsoever, and was placed at the bottom of the package. And some bubble wrap was placed on top. It is the hard drive protecting the bubble wrap? You have to see how some packages are thrown to the ground. And throwing a 8TB hard drive which is like a metal block to the ground is not a good thing. If the hard drive dies after 10 days or 1 year, you might not have to wonder why. Use your heart for the world, including packaging a hard drive.
customer_reviews.author: Epsilon Delta

customer_reviews.title: Love the drives - NOT IMPRESSED WITH THE DELIVERY PACKAGING!
customer_reviews.text: the drive is a NAS drive. I ordered them and they arrived pack in a 7" deep box with no padding. it appears they were just thrown in the box with 1 -24" strand of deflated cushion wrap. only one 4"x3" pad was inflated. these sensitive pieces of electronics took quite a beating it appears. Not impressed with the packaging. I am going to try them out and if they fail I will be returning the items. the 2nd photo is how I have always received the drives in prior orders. Separate boxes, supported and cushioned. NOT IMPRESSED
customer_reviews.author: James D.

customer_reviews.title: SHIPPED A 4 YEAR OLD USED DRIVE WITH 1735 DAYS POWER ON TIME
customer_reviews.text: PRODUCT IS USED AND OUT OF WARRANTY. Went to WD to register it and got warranty expired on 10/5/2016! When I pull SMART data it shows 1735 days power on time! that's older than the PC i put it in!!! DO NOT BUY FROM AMS TECHNOLOGIES INC THEY WILL SHIP USED TRASH TO YOU
customer_reviews.author: A. McQuade

customer_reviews.title: Warranty Worthless - WD Will Not Honor It
customer_reviews.text: The three year warranty on the listing means nothing; WD will not honor it. I purchased a WD Red NAS drive May 2019 from Amazon. October 2019, the drive has unreadable sectors during copy operations. The drive has a factory manufacture date stamp of November 10th, 2018. The listing for this product on Amazon shows a three year warranty. I attempted to register the drive on the WD website and RMA the drive, but they are claiming it is an OEM unit and/or a third-party vendor issue and that the warranty has been voided.
customer_reviews.author: Megan & John

customer_reviews.title: Great, Reliable Storage Solution
customer_reviews.text: I got this drive to replace another, smaller 6TB WD Red drive that I have been using for about 5 years. It has been a reliable solution for my storage needs. Keep in mind, if you plan to use these drives with an external enclosure, you will want to make sure the enclosure is rated for the large storage capacity. I usually pop these drives into an enclosure and clone the old drive. The last drive I upgraded from a 6TB to a 10TB and my enclosure wouldn't recognize the drive. After some troubleshooting, I realized that it was an issue with the enclosure. I grabbed another enclosure rated for the larger drives and it worked like a champ.
customer_reviews.author: J. Naylor

customer_reviews.title: Amazon is shipping old stock  (has a 2014 date code)
customer_reviews.text: Amazon is shipping old stock (has a 2014 date code). Four plus years is concerning.
customer_reviews.author: KTM

customer_reviews.title: Faulty: "08-Too many bad sectors detected" By WDC's diagnostic tool.
customer_reviews.text: It is unfortunately that the WD Red 4TB drive I received is a faulty HDD which is not expected. I just received yesterday and tested it immediately by using WD’s Data Lifeguard Diagnostic tool. The Quick Test result is okay but it failed on Extended Test with error of “08-Too many bad sectors detected”. I repeated the same test again but still it’s failed. I have been using various WD HDDs for long time on laptops and desktop PCs and have never had any issue before. WD Red Drive is a bit more expensive than Seagate IronWolf and I was hoping better quality but it seems not necessary.
customer_reviews.author: Gordon

customer_reviews.title: Reliable and consistent drive
customer_reviews.text: These drives I have been using for a long time in the NAS array. Years. They are very reliable and consistent. Mine operate 24/7, always spinning. The drives don't run forever (they are mechanical), but they are very predictable when they should be replaced. I try to keep 2 on hand when i know they are reaching the end of their hours. I have had one fail in the first 200 hours (out of like 10), but the exchange process is quick and painless online. Generally, if they break 500 hours, they will last a really long time.
customer_reviews.author: Josh K

customer_reviews.title: Failed just out of warranty, DO NOT BUY!!!
customer_reviews.text: Heed the warnings of everyone else in these comments. Just like many others, my drive failed 2 months out of the 3 year warranty. I now know why the warranty is 3 years and no longer or shorter than that. I do backups of all my data so I know I haven't lost anything, but I do know that I will no longer be trusting WD with my hard drive needs and will just buy the cheapest I can and backup my data. WD has definintely lost a customer for life in me, and I hopefully my experience will serve you well. Good luck!!!
customer_reviews.author: H.M.

customer_reviews.title: Delivered only in a plastic bag!
customer_reviews.text: I bought this as a direct replacement for a 5yo drive (exact model) that was failing. It arrived on my doorstep in a plastic bag. That's it. I'm sure this hard disk's wondrous journey through the transportation system included a variety of personal violations and hate crimes we don't yet have laws for. To no one's surprise, it did not work. One can only guess which drop, toss, or shake elicited its last breath.
customer_reviews.author: Sarah Wolf

customer_reviews.title: Best Drive on the market for NAS or home server needs.
customer_reviews.text: I had four 3TB WD Red drives running in a backup enclosure for nearly 7 years now with nary a hiccup. I've started updating my home server from regular commercial drives to 4TB WD Red drives and so far have been great. Just bought the last of the drives needed. You can build your NAS and/or home server with confidence these drives will last. They may not be the fastest drives, but that's not the point. They are built to run 24/7, and are low power. Here's to hoping I get another seven years out of my new home server and backup setup now that I'm using exclusively WD Red drives for all my backup needs.
customer_reviews.author: MTBDET

customer_reviews.title: Batch from Amazon was LOUD and broken. RMA'd them all.
customer_reviews.text: WD dries correctly are 5 star products, but out of 4 drives from Amazon one had critical errors within a month and all 4 were LOUD. I assumed this was something to do with them being NAS drives and was didn't realize how horribly loud and dysfunctional they were until I got the first drive RMA'd. Now I have RMA'd all drives I bought from Amazon and the replacements are all quiet and function. Zero issues with the RMA/support. I don't know if this stems from receiving product all from the same bad batch or if something in Amazon handling resulted in all the seemingly mechanical failures and noise related) issues.
customer_reviews.author: spaceguns

customer_reviews.title: Model number was not accurate
customer_reviews.text: The model was reported at a 'rx' which uses CMR, however when I checked the drive, I was shipped a 'ax' which is SMR. I didn't learn of this until the SMR/CMR WD scandal came out, which was well past the time period to try and get amazon to resolve., however when I checked all my drives, this one was in fact a 'AX'. So buyer be ware, check the model and make sure it's correct when you open it.
customer_reviews.author: I.B.

customer_reviews.title: No center mount holes
customer_reviews.text: WD has joined the pathetic Seagate clan in no longer drilling industry-standard center mount holes.
customer_reviews.author: Mets

customer_reviews.title: 12TB Western Digital Internal Hard Drives Fails
customer_reviews.text: This hard disk drive is unreliable: WD Red 12TB NAS Internal Hard Drive - 5400 RPM Class, SATA 6 GB/S, 256 MB Cache, 3.5" - WD120EFAX. Within two years I have had this hard drive replaced twice. I originally purchased this 12TB WD drive on, November 21, 2019. It worked until failing on, June 2020. It was replaced with a used 12TB WD drive by Western Digital in July 2020. The replacement Western Digital 12TB, received in July 2020, failed in, September 2020. Two 12TB Western Digital drives failing within 1 year. Unfortunate. Hard drives fail. Hopefully, the third drive will work out better.
customer_reviews.author: luckyduck

customer_reviews.title: NOT WD Dependable
customer_reviews.text: I have bought 14 of these drives since 2013 for my 2 NAS devices and I have had to replace 7 of them over the years, some still under warranty. I love WD and their products but these Red drives just don't have the longevity they should. Granted, they are only $79 a pop for the 3TB model but it's a bit ridiculous they are failing at this rate. The only reason I am not dropping to 3 stars is because my devices have hot swap drives for the storage volumes and it really only costs me 5 minutes to swap the drive and start the rebuild and I lose zero downtime.
customer_reviews.author: AmericanFight

customer_reviews.title: Great purchase
customer_reviews.text: I bought 8 of these, and only one of them needed RMA'd. I've bulk purchased many different drives from tons of other brands and 1 out of 8 for me is pretty acceptable. They're pretty quiet under full load, and have not had any performance issues yet. I have them installed in an 8-disk storage pool on Windows Server 2016, with double parity, data deduplication and thin provisioning enabled. I connect to the server with a 10gb direct connection, so hitting high 400's for reads and high 300's for writes is great. Your results may vary, but I've been nothing but happy with these drives. The performance is great and they've been running 24/7 for the last year without issue.
customer_reviews.author: Tom Love

customer_reviews.title: WD Quality isn't what it used to be
customer_reviews.text: I bought 4 of these a little less than 3 years ago to run in a RAID10 setup on an Ubuntu server. It's a media server that doesn't get a lot of traffic or use. Unfortunately, 2 out of the 4 are dead already well prior to their 3 year mark. Spent more than $800 on 4 of these and they should last longer than 2+ years. I've been a die hard Western Digital fan for years, but have been noticing quality issues with their drives more and more in the last few years. I won't be replacing these drives with WD, but looking at their competitors, unfortunately.
customer_reviews.author: Greg P

customer_reviews.title: Not in Original Packaging, Poor Shipping, BROKEN.
customer_reviews.text: Came in a UPS bag wrapped in some bubble wrap, in a waterproof bag. No box at all. Plugged it in, and it wouldn’t boot and made some audible clicking. Returning it today... Don’t k ow if it was new or refurbished, wouldn’t boot so couldn’t get power cycles. Update: Replacement item was shipped in the exact same way and the outcome was the same. Returning this item, won’t buy ever again. Went to Best Buy, purchased item off the shelf (from my car because of Covid-19) and it worked no issue.
customer_reviews.author: Cory

customer_reviews.title: Don't buy from Ellis Gadgets
customer_reviews.text: Absolutely terrible. Don't purchase this item from Ellis Gadgets. They ship in a bag. No box. No bubble wrap. A bag. Like I bought a loaf of bread. Obviously, the hard drive arrived damaged. No effort. Waste of time.
customer_reviews.author: P.L.

customer_reviews.title: Get this one, not the EFAX
customer_reviews.text: This is the normal WD RED drive to get. Do *not* get the EFAX version as that uses SMR (Shingled Magnetic Recording) and has very poor performance. Search for WD Red SMR to learn about why SMR is bad in NAS applications.
customer_reviews.author: SamMo

customer_reviews.title: simple replacement
customer_reviews.text: My Tivo died. Rather than order a new one and pay a ridiculous amount for lifetime activation, I decided to try to replace the hard drive. If it was the hardware itself rather than the drive, I can always add it to my PC. I popped it in and sat back and didn't have to do anything else. The setup went ahead, so I saved about $750. Great. The drive is quiet and my Tivo actually seems to operate with a little more spunk. Great price on a 2Tb drive.
customer_reviews.author: gary assassin

customer_reviews.title: EFRX drives are PMR, OK to use with ZFS
customer_reviews.text: If you are building a ZFS Storage Pool, you need to use PMR/CMR for your hard drives. The WD40EFRX uses PMR and is appropriate for use in ZFS Storage Pools. You should avoid the updated version of this drive, the 'WD40EFAX '. It uses SMR recording technology and will fail out of our ZFS pool when you resliver or scrub your pool. You have been warned.
customer_reviews.author: Jesse K Durfy

customer_reviews.title: Not as quick as i was expecting but I'm more worried about warranty/quality
customer_reviews.text: I didn't see any packets for warranty information and reading the reviews doesn't really help either so I'm hoping this drive lasts at least 4-5 years before crapping out. I'm starting to wonder if I should have just stuck with Seagate drives. I'll update this review when the drive dies though. Edit: June 17th, 2020 the drive just died. Didn't even last a year. I'd give 0 stars if possible. Time to submit a warranty claim for WD's POS engineering. My Toshiba drives lasted longer and were the same capacity from 2011. This is probably why Seagate is still #1 compared to WD being in dead last.
customer_reviews.author: Sobe

customer_reviews.title: DOA - no exchange allowed
customer_reviews.text: This drive arrived dead - unrecognized in Windows Disk Management and with access errors and unable to set up a storage pool with Synology Diskstation. Amazon offers to refund the $189 purchase price and submit a new order at $270. No, they will not exchange the broken drive for a working drive. Western Digital offers to replace the new broken drive (with its 3-year warranty) with a replacement drive with a 90-day warranty. Overall, a waste of more than two hours of my time.
customer_reviews.author: JustAnEngineer

customer_reviews.title: Great for the price.
customer_reviews.text: I ordered the 5400 RPM for durability over speed and it worked fine in a Sabrent USB 3.0 enclosure once I remember that for Windows you have to go to Control Panel/Administrative Tools/Computer Management/Storage/Disk Management and partition the disk. Once done the HD showed up a shy of 3TB because a 3tb drive is 3 trillion bits, when you convert that to bytes you get 2.72. I have used WD Green and WD Black and one thing you MUST do is register the drive. I have had failures in 1TB and 2TB drives and WD and other manufacturers have quickly replaced my drives based on the warranty period which can be 3-5 years.
customer_reviews.author: Fhteacher

customer_reviews.title: no warranty
customer_reviews.text: i just checked warranty on the two drives that I ordered and received today. according to wd website they have no warranty. i ordered 4 of the same sku about a year ago, they're under warranty until may of 2022. not sure what kind of shenanigans WD are engaged in here but this isnt good.
customer_reviews.author: Mark Twain

customer_reviews.title: Lasted exactly as long as warranty
customer_reviews.text: Great drive for 3 years and 2 months, then started having issues every time I did a regular backup. Windows could still see the device but any files on it would be unreachable, CHKDSK would report the disk as RAW but it still showed as NTFS in Windows. If I turned it off and back on it would work again till I tried running a backup again. Identified a files causing the problem, as long as they weren't accessed it would work fine. Funny the issue didn't start till pretty much exactly when the warranty ran out.
customer_reviews.author: J. Watkins

customer_reviews.title: Exactly what I was looking for
customer_reviews.text: I purchased an 8TB NAS last year, a WD pr2100 used exclusively for Plex. Using a Raid 1 configuration, i was left with roughly 4TB. Don't get me wrong, that's A LOT of space, but I managed to fill it up pretty quickly. I purchased 2 10TB drives with the hopes of upgrading my storage capacity and it worked like a charm!
customer_reviews.author: Taylor H.

customer_reviews.title: Lasted 4 years
customer_reviews.text: I have two of these that failed within a couple weeks of each other and were only four years old. Both made May 2015 failed March 2019. I am going to try these one more time and see how they do. In my opinion 4 years is not long enough in the capacity we were using them in. We only used it for weekly and monthly backups for a small business. We should have gotten more use out of these drives. I could have bought the more expensive drive with a longer warranty but I shouldn't have had too.
customer_reviews.author: Webb v

customer_reviews.title: Bought a pair to build a new file server
customer_reviews.text: I'm building a Linux based file server to replace my 10 year old server. Nothing wrong with the old server except it's getting a bit old. Ordered a pair of these when on sale. Can't say anything about longevity as they are new. So far, they are very quiet and work. I've had good luck with WD (non-RED) in my old server (4 Greens) and don't expect the REDs to be any different.
customer_reviews.author: CCW

customer_reviews.title: Great drive and amazing warranty
customer_reviews.text: I will only buy Western Digital hard drives from now on! I actually had an issue with this drive 2 days before the warranty ended and they replaced my drive with a completely new drive. I would never expect a company to stand by their product right before the warranty ends. The drive has worked very well in my Synology NAS. It has been online 24/7 for 2 years now, along with 11 other Western Digital hard drives in a Synology shared raid. I am a big of of this drive and Western Digital as a company.
customer_reviews.author: Dove Family

customer_reviews.title: Upgrading Capacity of My NAS
customer_reviews.text: My NAS has four bays. My drive in Bay #1 failed after 6 years of service, however the other three are still going strong, and happen to be WD 2-TB drives each. I replaced the drive in Bay #1 with this WD 4-TB drive, and it is working perfectly. Over the next couple of months, I will be replacing the other drives in order to expand my storage space. The replacements are basically plug and play, and I received my first replacement a lot quicker than expected about which I am very pleased.
customer_reviews.author: Buck

customer_reviews.title: Not super impressed
customer_reviews.text: Not as durable as I'd expect. We have two 8-bay NAS servers full of these things. The drives consistently fail after about 18-30 months of use. WD is good about replacing under warranty, but they send you refurb drives. We've yet to receive a refurbished drive that didn't have issues from the first day. The last refurb died after a few weeks. My overall impression of these drives is that they're the bare minimum (in terms of durability) to be called NAS drives. Make sure you have your data backed up elsewhere, even if using RAID with these things.
customer_reviews.author: Lexi

customer_reviews.title: 5 Year Warranty? Western Digital Disagrees
customer_reviews.text: I had two Reds die between the first and second year. They were both replaced with recertified drives, which isn't great, but I get it. Now, one of those drives has died, more than 3 years after but before the claimed 5 year warranty. They are refusing to replace the drive now. I'd look elsewhere for a drive, since WD isn't standing behind their warranty, which is still displayed as 5 years on this page! According to Western Digital support: "Please be informed that Western Digital has never sold WD Red drive with 5 years warranty. We are sorry to hear that you were misguided by the information shared by Amazon. "
customer_reviews.author: Josh

customer_reviews.title: Failed after 14 months
customer_reviews.text: I thought an NAS drive might make sense for the drive that stores my security video since it's written and overwritten so frequently. Purchased May 2019 Started blowing up with bad sectors two weeks ago, toxic, takes all the other drives down. I have many other non-NAS drives that have lasted many years. I reformatted and wrote zeros (supposedly that maps out bad sectors) and will see if I can get a second life out of it.
customer_reviews.author: K. Haplan

customer_reviews.title: Great and reliable
customer_reviews.text: If you have a NAS device, these are the only ones to have. WD red have always been solid and reliable. I had one die in a NAS several years ago. Bought a new one, plugged it in and the NAS took over and they worked great. If you have a NAS system, it isn’t worth the savings to get a cheaper drive, unless you don’t value your data. These are designed for NAS systems.
customer_reviews.author: T.K.

customer_reviews.title: WD Reds Are Great Drives For Synology NAS Builds
customer_reviews.text: Have used the WD Reds for years for all of my Synology NAS build-outs. They are well priced, solid performers & built to last. Have only had one fail in 7 years & I use Reds exclusively. Would highly recommend if you're building a NAS for small office or home use.
customer_reviews.author: WireHead

customer_reviews.title: If you have a NAS, this is the drive you want
customer_reviews.text: we run Netgear 4-drive rack mounted NAS. The RED is great. Runs slower, so less power, less heat, and no reason to need data faster than we get it. The RED is made for running 24/7. We had one fail that ran for five years, but running RAID, we bought a new one and never skipped a beat. This time, we upgraded all four from 2TB ea to 4TB. Good for another 5 years, and then we will replace and double again. By then, hard drives will be 50TB and thee 8TB we will need will be laughed at.
customer_reviews.author: John J Gill

customer_reviews.title: Lasted a couple of years
customer_reviews.text: I've always heard that RED drives were supposed to be better quality than the standard BLUE drives, but one of my drives failed within two years of regular use in a NAS. I replaced it with another RED drive, so hope it does better. My other RED drives of different sizes are doing fine so far, so it could have just been luck of the draw.
customer_reviews.author: Sacaudos

customer_reviews.title: Great storage to price ratio
customer_reviews.text: Western Digital is well known in the community on having some of the best support and easiest RMA process. I have had to return several WD drives over my years and they have won my support as a customer. This hard drive is a great price to storage ratio. As a "Red" drive it is great for NAS or other frequent access devices. I have this deployed 4 of these drives in my Synology 418play and they are working wonderfully. I expect them to last for many years.
customer_reviews.author: Dove Family

customer_reviews.title: Don't buy, WD Lied, NAS Arrays Died!
customer_reviews.text: Western Digital is using faulty technology which doesn't work for the use in NAS with their drives up to 6TB Red. Many NAS systems will flag the drives as faulty, and then perform even worse trying to rebuild the array. This switch was relatively recently, so you cannot go by older reviews, the new drives are fautly. WD has lied, got caught then shifted blame on this. Don't bother buying WD, HGST or SanDisk (which WD own).
customer_reviews.author: Tracker1

customer_reviews.title: Failed after 17 months of light use
customer_reviews.text: Had this drive for 17 months in a personal household QNAP NAS (not a business environment). Used it to store backups and media for the house. Everything was going good until the moment it died yesterday. I've had dozens of hard drives over the years, and this is the first one that died within 2 years of purchase. If you get this drive, you better have it in a RAID system because it will likely die on you. I have less trust in WD drives now as a result.
customer_reviews.author: GEH

customer_reviews.title: I am returning these drives and replacements are on the ...
customer_reviews.text: I am returning these drives and replacements are on the way. If the replacements are what I ordered and function properly in my Mobius, I will update this review. The drives I received were labeled as WD Red, but they clearly are not. The authentic WD Red drives have a SATA connector and a red label. The drives received have black labels and much older IDE pins. Update 7/2/16: I received two replacement drives, installed them in my Mobius, and they seem to be functioning properly. I'll update to 5 from 2 stars, though the first two drives I received were not sealed in their antistatic sleeves and were something other than ordered. Amazon promptly made the order right.
customer_reviews.author: Keith A. Swalley

customer_reviews.title: nas drive
customer_reviews.text: set up my desk top as a media server. this is the first drive. was able to map it use plex and burn dvds to it and stream to firestick or fire tv. now it was not that simple but with a little help got it done. do i need an nas drive for this use. i cant say but the nas drive is meant for constant duty where another drive might sleep. so far easy to burn to and easy to stream from. problem is with 1000 dvds im not sure i want to watch any of them. so its a work in progress.
customer_reviews.author: MICHAEL

customer_reviews.title: Great Drive with Zero Issues or Complaints
customer_reviews.text: I purchased two of these 1TB Red drives 5.5 years ago (Oct 2013). They're installed in a Synology NAS that's up almost 24/7. After 47437 hours of power-on time, one of the drives is finally showing degraded status (thresholded read error rate, sector reallocations, and long spin-up time). Though it has not yet fully failed, it's time to replace. Reading the reviews lately (2019), it seems WD quality may have dropped lately. I think I'll take the plunge and replace with another WD Red, however, since they've served me well so far.
customer_reviews.author: Al Dente

customer_reviews.title: GREAT PRICE GREAT DRIVE Synology 720+
customer_reviews.text: I was a bit concerned about buying these drives because of the reviews but it looks like WD made the changes they needed. Drive works great, its pretty fast and works well in my synology 720+ without any issues. For me this was just the right size for what I needed as a beginner. Typically I'm a seagate guy but for the price and quality this was a great deal. Will consider WD in the future.
customer_reviews.author: Rafeaky

customer_reviews.title: Nice HDDs for a Synology NAS.
customer_reviews.text: I really don't have anything to say about this HDD. (Which is a good thing.) I bought two for my Synology NAS backup box. And they work great. No problems. The installation was easy. It obviously took some time to format (and check the surface) -- that's just physics. So hopefully it will continue being that way. PS. For people looking to "save" by buying cheaper HDDs (cough, Seagate) I'd just say one thing -- DON'T! You'll regret it later when you'll end up paying thousands of $$'s to recover your backup when those cheaper drives fail. So far WD did not fail me. There were some hiccups but overall their HDDs are very reliable!
customer_reviews.author: DC

customer_reviews.title: Unable to receive a unit that worked
customer_reviews.text: After two attempts, I still did not receive a unit that worked. The first unit screamed when put in the Drobo it was supposed to upgrade. The Drobo would not recognize it. The second unit was a bit quieter, but the Drobo would still not recognize it. Assuming that, perhaps, the Drobo was as fault, I looked around for another device to try the unit in. Given the covid thing it was difficult to locate someone to help me out. By the time I did (and the unit was at fault) it was past time to return it.
customer_reviews.author: WAH

customer_reviews.title: Well Built Hard Drive
customer_reviews.text: I pretty got this for my ps4 when I upgraded it’s storage. Use to have a lot of problems with frame drops but after installing it everything runs smoothly. I’ve had this for over 2 years now and it still working perfectly. I don’t know too much about hard drives but this is amazing. Though do your research on what you need this may not work for you. I also got the warranty incase it ever failed but it hasn’t yet. Definitely love this just such great quality.
customer_reviews.author: Camacho

customer_reviews.title: Good drive for a backup / NAS application
customer_reviews.text: I'm using this in a server for local backup of the primary drives (running WD blacks for faster data rate on the fileshares). This drive is on 24/7 and I am ok with slower transfer rate for nightly backups, so it was a great choice. Would purchase again.
customer_reviews.author: E.T.

customer_reviews.title: Great little drive for OMV and PLEX running off a Raspberry Pi.
customer_reviews.text: I got this drive to use with a Raspberry Pi I had laying around with OpenMediaVault (OMV) and using it as a PLEX server as well. Powered the drive with "UGREEN SATA to USB Cable USB 3.0 to Hard Drive Adapter Converter for 2.5 3.5 Inch Hard Drive Disk HDD SATA III and SSD Support UASP with 12V 2A Power Adapter" and designed an enclosure that I 3D printed. The drive has been running non-stop (well, not really, but you know what I mean) for a little over two months now. No issues.
customer_reviews.author: Chris H.

customer_reviews.title: So disappointed and upset with WD quality has gone out the window
customer_reviews.text: Used this as a main backup for all my data from many years of computing, I kept it in a cool dry spot in the top of my closet in an enclosed case and pulled it out 2 times to load more recent data, third time I pulled it out everything was corrupted and the volumes didn't exist. I'm attempting data recovery but most of it looks completely destroyed. Luckily I kept my old hard drive I was backing up to so I only lost less than a years worth of data. I used the drive 3 times in under a year and now it's garbage. NEVER BUY WD RED DRIVES!!!!!!!!!!!!
customer_reviews.author: AmazonUser

customer_reviews.title: One failed few weeks ago
customer_reviews.text: I ordered two of these in 2017 for my Synology NAS. These worked as intended. experience no issues during these years. Only a few weeks ago, my Synology started reporting bad sectors in one of these drives. As per recommendation i ran a SMART test on it (which ran of 14 hours) and now the system is reporting that drive is failing. Mind you that i am using NAS for desktop backup only. Not running Plex or any other media server. So I give this product 3 stars (actually 2.5 stars) because out of two drives, one is working fine till now and one has tanked.
customer_reviews.author: RJ

customer_reviews.title: Dropped dead after 18 months.
customer_reviews.text: Drives just ain't what they used to be. Good price, but not if you are replacing them that quickly. Bought 5 of these drives for a NAS package, one went bad, and no sooner had I replaced the first one, a second one joined its brother. All I need is for the other three to decide to go all at once... --- two more dropped dead almost simultaneously. Incredibly lucky my NAS device is fault tolerant for up to two drives. Moving to Seagate.
customer_reviews.author: John T. Kaylor

customer_reviews.title: Works in A1409 Time Capsule
customer_reviews.text: I recently picked up a used Apple A1409 Time Capsule as I’m now up to seven Macs with various size drives. I just added up all the drives and multiplied by two to have room for changes throughout the month. While my three QNAP NAS units have support for Time Machine protocol, I wanted to keep the data off the NAS because backups were getting huge. This was only for ease of restoring the machine in case something went wrong. It installed and formatted just fine. It recognizes the 10 terabyte drive without issues. It’s quiet, and doesn’t run much hotter than the Western Digital Caviar Green 2 terabyte that was in the unit previously.
customer_reviews.author: Philip Godfrey

customer_reviews.title: Not the most reliable.
customer_reviews.text: I've had two complete failures of these drives in three years and four months of use of use in a WD NAS unit. That's a 50% failure rate. The first failure was at 2 years and was under warranty. The second failure was at 3 years and two months and was not under warranty. Both failures were successfully recovered by the NAS box, and I bought two more of these to insure future availability of identical drives.
customer_reviews.author: Huffy49

customer_reviews.title: Failed After 500 Hours
customer_reviews.text: I bought two of these back in 2015 to upgrade my NAS. I installed one - which has roughly 30000 hours and counting - and a second one to keep as a backup in case one of my older drives fails. I eventually ran out of space on my NAS before my other 2TBs failed and decided to upgrade with my backup. The extra 3TB backup drive I've had sitting still in the original unopened box failed after 500 hours. I've only ever used WD HDDs and have been satisfied for the most part (I have almost 10 years on some of my HDDs), but it was disappointing that my 3TB backup drive failed so quickly.
customer_reviews.author: Bryon

customer_reviews.title: Dependability equals Western Digital
customer_reviews.text: When ever I am in the market to purchase an HDD, my first choice is always Western Digital. I have been in the IT field for over 30 years and I have seen HDD's manufactured by competitors fail as soon as within a month but have never seen a WD HDD have issues until 5 years later in a 24x7 environment. If you are looking for reliable storage, Western Digital should be your first choice. I purchased a pair of WD Red HDD's for my NAS server and they work great.
customer_reviews.author: DanDaMan

customer_reviews.title: used this for my tivo roamio
customer_reviews.text: Not much to say. I bought a different WD nas drive that had a 256 mb cache and it did not work. I plugged this WD30EFRX into my tivo and it worked. It took a few minutes for it to self format but it is literally plug in the new hard drive and go through the set up process. It is quiet and now I have 3 tb or available storage to record over the air tv shows.
customer_reviews.author: livingaboard

customer_reviews.title: TL;DR  Ordered 2 drives and 1 was DOA.
customer_reviews.text: TL;DR Ordered 2 drives and 1 was DOA. Ordered 2 4TB WD RED drives to replace 2 3TB WD GREEN drives in my Drobo 5N that have both been subject to "healing" activity in the Drobo. As they had been there for a few years I thought it would be a good time to upgrade to the RED drives that are designed for NAS operation. The first drive went in fine and the Drobo did its work and got things straight. Then I added the second drive a few days later and it immediately failed. Just to check I added this "failed drive" to my other Drobo and it still did not work. Very unhappy about this.
customer_reviews.author: DM - Blue

customer_reviews.title: Ordered April 2019 - received NasWare 3.0
customer_reviews.text: The photos on the Amazon page are confusing - in the photo the product label states NasWare 2.0 which is old. I received my order 23rd April 2019 (Red 4TB WD40EFRX) and the label says NasWare 3.0 with a manufacture date of 13th March 2019. I'm happy with this. Installing the hard disk now into a NAS drive (WD EX2 Ultra). UPDATE: one week in the NAS drive and everything working as expected. This drive runs cooler (40o) than an older WD drive (49o) that I initially used in the NAS drive. All good for now.
customer_reviews.author: nuts67

customer_reviews.title: Works great!
customer_reviews.text: I have purchased these drives I believe 2 year ago, I am finally just getting around to reviewing it. So far these drives have done well. I have this in my Qnap which has had multiple power interruptions and all 4 drives are still running strong with no uncorrectable errors. One thing though, I did get this as opposed to the Hitachi brand because they say it's quieter, however if it's in the bedroom, it's not the quietest thing, you can still hear a lot of the read and writes. These are great drives, no issues so far!
customer_reviews.author: Big Dawgs Fam

customer_reviews.title: Two happily living together in a Synology ds2012
customer_reviews.text: Having outgrown my aging Time Capsule and finding a great deal on a DS2012, I filled it with two of these drives, in a mirrored configuration. There's a noticeable "whoosh" when they start, but everything seems fast and reliable. There's not a lot to say about modern drives. People love them until they fail, then they hate them. So far, for these drives, I'm still in the first.
customer_reviews.author: Robert

customer_reviews.title: Work fine with Supermicro X11-SSM/Freebsd 12.0 ZFS
customer_reviews.text: Our motherboard detected these no problem. You can use them as regular drives even though they are technically for NAS. Remember that disks fail, no matter what brand they are, that’s the nature of the beast. They are mass produced, that’s why they’re so cheap. Don’t buy into excessively negative rants about HDs. As to why some disks fail and others don’t, there are too many variables involved. Some people fry them with static electric discharge before installation, others install them improperly, etc.
customer_reviews.author: J. Noor

customer_reviews.title: Tried and True
customer_reviews.text: I bought 4 of these 4TB drives to work in my Synology DS918+. Even though from everything I read, I still wanted some redundancy, so I used their hybrid array giving me almost 10TB of storage. I'm not happy about losing a drive to redundancy, but it's better than the consequences. So far these are running like a champ with no issues. Easy to install. They provide both screws and non-screw option of installation depending on your needs. Luckily the diskstation didn't need the screws, so they were easy as putting on the plastic drive adapters. Easy peazy.
customer_reviews.author: wanfixer

customer_reviews.title: High quality at a decent price
customer_reviews.text: Had gone through 3 4TB Seagate Barracuda drives for my Synology NAS, all of which were either DOA or died within days of installation,and I then installed 2 of these and have had absolutely no problems at all. I have been a dedicated customer of Seagate for many years, but their quality has dropped into the bottom of the ocean. Glad to see that Western Digital is selling a high quality drive at a reasonable price.
customer_reviews.author: CharlieTX

customer_reviews.title: Not impressed. This drive died in my raid well ...
customer_reviews.text: Not impressed. This drive died in my raid well before others that are 10X older and used more. When I tried to get the drive warrantied I had to pay for the shipping just to find out they sent me a re-certified drive with scratches all over it. I have been loyal to western digital for sometime, but I will now not be buying their products for me or my clients. Cheap and unreliable.
customer_reviews.author: hostile

customer_reviews.title: Amazingly Reliable Drive
customer_reviews.text: I've never trusted any drive more than these WD Red series. Since I've been purchasing these for my server, I've never had (knock on wood, knock on wood, knock on wood) a drive failure in years, that was at the cause of old age. I've had a drive failure, but that was due to a power outage. These drives are robust, fast and keep going! I can very EASILY recommend these for any build that you expect to be powered on 24/7, with reliability at hand. Still, it is ALWAYS smart to have a form of redundancy. Back up your stuff! Run a RAID configuration! Then back up again!
customer_reviews.author: SirEpicIndividual

customer_reviews.title: One of the best
customer_reviews.text: Excellent product, WD Reds are good for NAS but I had some failures between the hundreds of units that I installed. However, their warranty returns and RMAs are easy to start and it happened with a few units only. At this price point, it's good business.
customer_reviews.author: J. Cohen

customer_reviews.title: Works in Synology NAS.
customer_reviews.text: I ordered two of these drive for my Synology NAS. I've had them installed for just a few months but have had no issues with them. A small note is that they are very easy to hear when they are being written / read. They are not the quietest hard drives. This may not be an issue for most unless the NAS is going to be in an area that is noise sensitive.
customer_reviews.author: G. Davies

customer_reviews.title: Air filled  - More power consumption
customer_reviews.text: WD drives are normally very good drives. I haven't had them long enough for them to burn out yet... But with the 101EFAX drives, they may (and probably are) filled with air vs helium filled drives. Subtle difference but the air filled seems to cause more power consumption, and is causing the noise level to raise up a little bit. Something to note.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Home-NAS system, serves up media files and data storage perfectly
customer_reviews.text: I bought these to fill my Synology 5 Bay NAS DiskStation DS1517 and they work perfectly. No complaints. I store digital movies and music files and play them back over my home network, and I've never noticed a lag. It's important to understand the difference between the "red label" and other discs from WD. The Red line is specifically designed for the demands of network attached storage. They're potentially overkill for a desktop system, but if you're going to the trouble and expense of setting up a home or small office NAS this is the way to go.
customer_reviews.author: Dave

customer_reviews.title: Drive failed after less than 6 months of use.
customer_reviews.text: I installed this drive in my Drobo 5N at the end of November, 2016. Yesterday, April 16th, 2017 the drive failed. That's less than 6 months of operation before failure. The WD Red series is supposed to be more reliable than standard hard drives. Of course failure at any time is always possible, but it doesn't leave me feeling very secure about these hard drives. Amazon, however, really came through for me, and worked with me to get a replacement under warranty, so Kudos to Amazon!
customer_reviews.author: David S. Bunin

customer_reviews.title: Does not work in Hotswap rack
customer_reviews.text: I have a stack of 3 ICYDOCK 971's and the disk writes very sloooowly in all racks. If I connect the disk directly with the same SATA cable and port on the MB the drive works to spec's. Other drives like Seagate run just fine. I searched and found that other's have the same problem with WD's using other hot swap racks and no solutions. I fell two days outside of being able to return the disk to Amazon. I'll have to eat this one but it will be my last Western Digital drive.
customer_reviews.author: Bruce Jonsson

customer_reviews.title: 4tb Red Review
customer_reviews.text: I've predominantly stuck with Hitachi drives due to their reputation of reliability, but decided to give WD a shot this time around for a freenas build (since they purchased HGST). Instead of gambling with externals, I specifically ordered bare drives instead of shucking as I only needed 12-13tbs usable space. None of the six 4tbs I ordered failed their week marathon of torture testing with badblocks, even with Amazon's hilariously bad packaging for mechanical drives, so props to WD on constructing something that can survive UPS ground. All-in-all, I am satisfied with my purchase and would purchase WD drives again. Probably not through Amazon though, unless they fix their packaging for hard drives.
customer_reviews.author: Jeremy

customer_reviews.title: Ask me after it hasn't failed in five years...
customer_reviews.text: I run Western Digital where I can, and I'm an IT consultant, so I USE my machines. I run a small VMWare cloud off WD NAS boxes at home -- these two drives went into the NAS supporting that cloud via iSCSI. I've used other hard disks from Toshiba and Seagate and had them fail after short run-times. That's not to say they NEVER fail, but in my experience, they last two to three times longer than competing brands. I have a MyBook on my desk that is probably eight years old.
customer_reviews.author: Stephen Cohrs

customer_reviews.title: Not as much useable space as expected.
customer_reviews.text: Installed 5 drives should have been 20 TB, but expected to lose a little each drive 17-18 TB. But after install and RAID build wound up with 13.8 TB. That’s more than 1 drive space lost. Just be aware you don’t get full amount per drive. I’ve used WD NAS drives for 15-20 years without issues. Other manuf. tho I found failures too frequent.
customer_reviews.author: WearAll Hats

customer_reviews.title: Ordered two drives, both were dead within two days
customer_reviews.text: Ordered two of these drives for a new NAS being set up. One drive was DOA and didn't work at all when first connected, so it was immediately returned. I ordered a third drive to replace the bad one. Before the new drive even arrived, the second drive was also dead. Now I will be returning the second dead drive for a refund, as well as the third drive which hasn't arrived and going with a different brand. I can chalk up one bad drive to being a fluke, but after having both drives go bad within two days I don't have much confidence that replacements will do any better.
customer_reviews.author: gold

customer_reviews.title: Bought 2 1TB drives, died, repalced, died : will switch brand
customer_reviews.text: They were 1TB drives. They were barely used because I used them as backup drive. Both died within 3 years warranty, and replacement refurbished disks died briefly. I feel my money was being stolen. I will buy from other manufacturer next time.
customer_reviews.author: JustAGeek

customer_reviews.title: Works well, easy to set up.
customer_reviews.text: Arrived in a sealed anti-static bag and packaged nicely in a plain brown box. Easy to set up, I use it with a Thermaltake BlacX single drive docking station (USB 3.0). I transferred 244gb in about 1 hour 2 minutes without errors. So far so good.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: You can't beat the price for the amount of storage they have and I like that they are specifically designed for NAS use
customer_reviews.text: I installed two of these in the My Cloud PR4100 NAS server I use for my home network. You can't beat the price for the amount of storage they have and I like that they are specifically designed for NAS use. I have yet to see any issues with noise or temperature and I was able to easily copy my photo and music files from a secondary drive in my main computer to the server within a reasonable amount of time, considering the size of both libraries. I plan to purchase two more Red drives in the future but will probably wait for storage space to increase, which should translate to a price drop in these and similarly sized drives.
customer_reviews.author: F&D

customer_reviews.title: USELESS DRIVE. I bought this drive to archive projects
customer_reviews.text: USELESS DRIVE. I bought this drive to archive projects. I remounted it after 4-5 months and it's dead. Not recognized by the OS, with no spin-up. I've pretty much mounted it twice after I bought it for archiving, and now I have to kiss the work goodbye. I'm going back to Hitachi HGST Deskstars and Ultrastars. Even though WD owns them, they have been hands-off on quality control. Perhaps WD needs to spend more time with them instead.
customer_reviews.author: motionmonk

customer_reviews.title: Solid drives
customer_reviews.text: I bought 4 of these drives to populate half of a home NAS. After running conveyance, short, and long S.M.A.R.T. tests, they got a burn in for about 24 hours. No failures in the batch. Since then, they have run 24/7 with no problems. Recently, I replaced them with 8x8TB Reds and they handled the week of data transfer in stride while still managing daily work load. All four still test fine. As long as you're not expecting speed, you'll be more than pleased with how these perform.
customer_reviews.author: sam chapler

customer_reviews.title: Dead 5 months after warranty runs out
customer_reviews.text: Bought in June 2016. Dead due to bad sectors in December 2019. Warranty expired in June 2019. Worked great until it didn't. 31,000 hours and 275 power on count on the drive. Replaced with a refurb server farm drive. At least if it fails then I won't be out a lot of money. No reason to buy a drive this expensive that fails just outside the warranty.
customer_reviews.author: Pig Benis

customer_reviews.title: Really nice
customer_reviews.text: The picture is obviously different than the product but it is exactly what they promised was very exited when it arrived it took a minute to install because I had to unplug everything in the way from the drive dock where it would sit and had to unfasten the old one. It is very quiet it is a very very low quiet hum can hardly notice it unless trying to listen for it very fast speed actually was impressive I ran a passmark test and scored at about 60 percentile of PCs
customer_reviews.author: Avery Benzing

customer_reviews.title: Purchased 2x in Oct 2019 and one Failed already (Aug 2020)
customer_reviews.text: I purchased two of these and one has already failed in less than a year. Really disappointed in the quality . The HGST 3GB drives I bought in 2016 are still going strong. Yeah I know WD bought out Hitachi Global Storage Technologies. Oh well, WD rotating disk are history. High capacity, low noise and ease of install mean nothing if Reliability is ^$#%$@#@ !!! Manufactured May19, 2019 - Failed Aug 14, 2020 - Not interested in a refurbished replacement TYVM
customer_reviews.author: Mike T

customer_reviews.title: Long term usage works fine
customer_reviews.text: I've been using this drive for about two years straight as part of a media server (yes, I SEVERELY underestimated sapce requirements). It's quietly ran non-stop essentially for those two years and taken more than a few bumps from clumsy cats without missing a beat or losing a file. It's replacement is the same drive just a larger 8TB capacity (x3). Just make sure to not cheap out and buy the smaller drives!
customer_reviews.author: D. Pike

customer_reviews.title: Rebuild QNAP Raid 5 Array with other "WD60EFRX" drives that were 2/3 years old with no errors.
customer_reviews.text: Arrived as expect from Amazon on time. Was concerning about Manufacture date of drive, and was happy to see it was Apr/2018. Purchased to replace a failed WD Red 6tb in my 4 bay QNAP TS-469, and this matching "WD60EFRX" synced up fine with the other "WD60EFRX" disks in the array that are 2/3 years older. No errors reported on the drive after Raid 5 array rebuilt. Very happy with WD Red drives in general and that years after being released, they still have same models to replace drives that fail! :)
customer_reviews.author: SciFi-Fan

customer_reviews.title: 1/4 failed within 48 hours
customer_reviews.text: This drive is making me nervous, never a good thing for a backup drive. I bought 3 of them. Installed in a DROBO 5N2 (network model). Copied about 1.6 TB of data to the system. Two days later one of the drives failed. I bought another one and installed it, so far so good (only 2 days in). Backup NAS drives failing that early makes me really question my choice. Hopefully it was a one off problem. Usually when a drive fails it will fail early. I am hoping that is the case here.
customer_reviews.author: Jason Short

customer_reviews.title: WD HHD Great Name with Great price
customer_reviews.text: I search online not able to find the batter price we got it from here. Product is great put on NAS system for back of data I am very with product and quality of WD HSS
customer_reviews.author: Daniel

customer_reviews.title: Most likely a great drive
customer_reviews.text: Worked great for about 35 days. I needed to change something inside my server case so I pulled it out along with my other drives from the hot swap bay to lighten the case. Then I DROPPED IT about 12" as I was about to re-install it back into the bay. FU@%$&%!!!!!!!!! Not any of the older, smaller drives mind you. The brand new larger drive. GDISM!!!!! Totally dead.
customer_reviews.author: Dan H.

customer_reviews.title: So far so good.
customer_reviews.text: So far so good. They’re sitting quietly as backup drives at the bottom of my case. They do the job and I can’t hear them over the computer fans and and/or any other ambient home sounds. Packaging was not fancy; minimal - maybe better for the environment that way?  ̄\_(ツ)_/ ̄
customer_reviews.author: Nadmiral

customer_reviews.title: I know the HDD Drive is an Old Tech but Capacity is Good 8TB
customer_reviews.text: WD is the best for Hard Disks, amazing Quality, i'd like to get SSD instead of HDD because it's Lighter, no noise and a much cooler temp, but i really need bigger Tera Bytes that why i bought this 8TB and there's an option unit 20TB from WD but it's so heavy and it need power cord, my wish NVme is the Future for Hard Disk Capacity reach 100TB as an option, Trusted Seller and thank you so much!
customer_reviews.author: Wahub
